18 May 1995 Anderson Hills tornado: A tornado which touched down near Huntsville, Alabama killed one person.
Premio Lo Nuestro 1995: An awards ceremony was held in Miami for Latin music.
19 May 1995 Big Ten Conference Baseball Tournament: The Ohio State Buckeyes won the final game of a double-elimination college baseball conference tournament in Columbus, Ohio.
20 May 1995 Preakness Stakes: Timber Country won a running of the Preakness Stakes in Baltimore.
1995 Kids' Choice Awards: An awards ceremony for popular culture was held in Houston.
21 May 1995 Atlantic Coast Conference Baseball Tournament: The Florida State Seminoles won the final game of a double-elimination college baseball conference tournament in Greenville, South Carolina.
1995 Southwest Conference Baseball Tournament: The Texas Tech Red Raiders won the final game of a double-elimination college baseball conference tournament in College Station, Texas.
22 May The Supreme Court reached a decision in Wilson v. Arkansas in which it held that police officers must knock and announce before entering a house to serve a warrant.
The Supreme Court held in a decision in First Options of Chicago, Inc. v. Kaplan that a court may review a contract in any circumstance where the parties have not clearly agreed to arbitration.
In a decision in U.S. Term Limits, Inc. v. Thornton, the Supreme Court held that states cannot impose qualifications for prospective members of Congress stricter than those specified in the Constitution, invalidating the term limit provisions of some twenty states.
An amendment to the Paperwork Reduction Act was passed, extending the authority of the Office of Information and Regulatory Affairs over agency orders to provide information to the public.
27 May May 1995 tornado outbreak sequence: The outbreak ended, after leaving thirteen dead across the country.
28 May 1995 Indianapolis 500: Jacques Villeneuve won a running of the Indianapolis 500 in Speedway, Indiana.
1995 Coca-Cola 600: Bobby Labonte won a running of what is now the Sprint Cup Series in Charlotte, North Carolina.
29 May 1995 Great Barrington tornado: A tornado which touched down in Great Barrington, Massachusetts killed three.
31 May 1995 NCAA Division I Outdoor Track and Field Championships: A college track and field tournament began in which the Arkansas Razorbacks would top the men's standings and the LSU Lady Tigers the women's.
June 1 68th Scripps National Spelling Bee: Justin Tyler Carroll won a spelling bee in Washington, D.C.
The United States and the United Kingdom defined their maritime border in the Caribbean Sea.
June 4 49th Tony Awards: An awards ceremony was held for Broadway theater.
1995 Miller Genuine Draft 500: Kyle Petty won a running of what is now the Sprint Cup Series in Dover, Delaware.
June 5 Hurricane Allison: A hurricane made landfall in Florida which would cause some two million dollars in damage before dissipating six days later.
June 10 1995 MTV Movie Awards: An awards ceremony was held for American cinema.
1995 NCAA Division I Baseball Tournament: The Cal State Fullerton Titans won the final of a college baseball tournament in Omaha, Nebraska.
June 12 The Supreme Court held in a decision in Adarand Constructors, Inc. v. Peña that racial classifications established by the federal government must meet the same standard of strict scrutiny as classifications established by the states.
The Supreme Court reached a decision in Missouri v. Jenkins in which it held that the remedies ordered by a district court to eliminate the de facto segregation of students in the Kansas City, Missouri School District, now Kansas City Public Schools, exceeded that court's authority.
June 14 1995 NBA Finals: The Houston Rockets defeated the Orlando Magic in the finals in four games, the last in Houston.
June 18 1995 U.S. Open: Corey Pavin won a U.S. Open golf tournament held in Shinnecock Hills, New York.
June 19 The Supreme Court reached a decision in Hurley v. Irish-American Gay, Lesbian, & Bisexual Group of Boston in which it held that private citizens holding a public demonstration may not be compelled to include participants with whom they disagree.
June 21 The Supreme Court held in a decision in Florida Bar v. Went For It, Inc. that a Florida law prohibiting lawyers from reaching out to victims within the first thirty days after an accident did not violate the First Amendment.
The Supreme Court reached a decision in Vernonia School District 47J v. Acton in which it held that random drug testing of student athletes by public schools serves a reasonable government interest and does not therefore violate the Fourth Amendment.
June 24 1995 Stanley Cup Finals: The New Jersey Devils defeated the Detroit Red Wings in the fourth game of the finals in East Rutherford, New Jersey, winning the series.
June 25 King of the Ring: A World Wrestling Federation event took place in Philadelphia.
1995 U.S. Cup: The United States team won the final game of a soccer tournament in Piscataway, New Jersey.
June 26 Death of Jason Callahan: Jason Callahan was killed in a vehicle accident in Emporia, Virginia.
Democratic congressman Greg Laughlin of Texas's 14th congressional district changed parties to become a Republican.
June 27 Miss Texas USA 1996: Kara Williams won a Miss Texas USA pageant in South Padre Island, Texas, advancing to the Miss USA pageant.
June 29 STS-71: The space shuttle Atlantis docked in orbit with the Russian space station Mir.
The Supreme Court held in a decision in Capitol Square Review & Advisory Board v. Pinette that private religious expression in a public forum does not violate the Establishment Clause.
In a decision in Miller v. Johnson, the Supreme Court held that obvious gerrymandering for the purposes of creating majority-minority Congressional districts violates the Equal Protection Clause.
The Supreme Court reached a decision in Rosenberger v. University of Virginia in which it held that the University of Virginia's denying funds available to other student publications to a publication produced from a religious viewpoint did not uphold the Establishment Clause but in fact violated the First Amendment's guarantee of freedom of speech.
Sunrayce 95: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology won a solar car race from Indianapolis to Golden, Colorado.
July 1 1995 Special Olympics World Summer Games: A sporting contest for intellectually disabled athletes opened in New Haven, Connecticut.
July 11 The United States restored full diplomatic relations with Vietnam.
Heat wave of 1995 derecho series: The first of a series of derechos appeared over Montana.
1995 Major League Baseball All-Star Game: The National League beat the American League in an all-star game of Major League Baseball in Arlington, Texas.
July 12 1995 Chicago heat wave: A heat wave began in the Midwest which would kill more than seven hundred people in Chicago over the next four days.[640][641]
July 13 Detroit newspaper strike of 1995–97: Employees of the newspapers the Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News went on strike in protest of unfair labor practices.
July 14 UFC 6: An Ultimate Fighting Championship event was held in Casper, Wyoming.
July 15 1995 Total Petroleum 200: Butch Miller won a running of what is now the Camping World Truck Series in Erie, Colorado.
July 16 1995 Miller Genuine Draft 500: Dale Jarrett won a running of what is now the Sprint Cup Series in Long Pond, Pennsylvania.
1995 U.S. Women's Open Golf Championship: Annika Sörenstam won a golf tournament in Colorado Springs, Colorado.
July 21 11th TCA Awards: An awards ceremony for television was held in Pasadena, California.
July 29 1995 Women's U.S. Cup: The first game of a round robin women's soccer tournament took place in Worcester, Massachusetts.
July 30 Tropical Storm Dean: A tropical storm which would cause half a million dollars over the next three days made landfall in Texas.
July 31 1995 Toshiba Classic: A hardcourt tennis tournament opened in San Diego.
August 1 Murder of Charles Blankenship: Charles Blankenship was shot and killed on his neighbor's porch in Cincinnati.
August 2 Hurricane Erin: A hurricane made landfall in Florida which would cause some seven hundred million dollars in damage in the United States over the next four days.
Bill Clinton issued Executive Order 12968, an executive order which standardized processes for granting federal employees access to classified information with a view to ending discrimination against homosexuals in granting such access.
August 5 1995 Brickyard 400: Dale Earnhardt won a running of what is now the Sprint Cup Series in Indianapolis.
August 7 1995 Thriftway ATP Championships: A men's hardcourt tennis tournament opened in which Andre Agassi would win the singles and Todd Woodbridge and Mark Woodforde the doubles.
August 8 Democratic congressman Billy Tauzin of Louisiana's 3rd congressional district changed parties to become a Republican.
August 10 1995 Pan Pacific Swimming Championships: A swimming competition opened in Atlanta.
1995 World Wrestling Championships: A wrestling contest opened in Atlanta.
August 13 1995 PGA Championship: Steve Elkington won a Professional Golf Association tournament in Los Angeles.
August 14 1995 Volvo International: A hardcourt tennis tournament opened in New Haven, Connecticut in which Andre Agassi would win the singles and Rick Leach and Scott Melville the doubles.
August 15 Miss Teen USA 1995: Keylee Sue Sanders won a beauty pageant held in Wichita, Kansas.
August 21 Atlantic Southeast Airlines Flight 529: A commercial flight from Hartsfield–Jackson Atlanta International Airport to Gulfport, Mississippi crashed in Carroll County, Georgia, killing nine.
August 23 Tropical Storm Jerry: A tropical storm made landfall at Jupiter, Florida which would kill six people.
August 24 Operation Vigilant Sentinel: The 74th Air Control Squadron deployed to Kuwait in response to the massing of Iraqi forces on the border.
August 25 First Roller In-line Hockey World Championship: The United States team won a roller in-line hockey championship game in Villa Park, Illinois.
August 26 1995 Little League World Series: The Little League team of Tainan won a Little League championship tournament in Williamsport, Pennsylvania.
August 27 Hurricane Luis: A tropical depression, later a hurricane, formed in the Atlantic Ocean which would kill two people in the United States before dissipating some two weeks later.
1995 U.S. Open Cup: The Richmond Kickers won the final match of a soccer tournament in El Paso, Texas.
August 28 Markale massacres: The Army of Republika Srpska (BPC) shelled an open-air market in Sarajevo, killing forty civilians.
1995 US Open: An outdoor hardcourt tennis tournament opened in New York City.
August 30 Operation Deliberate Force: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) began punitive airstrikes against BPC targets.
September 1 ArenaBowl IX: The Tampa Bay Storm defeated the Orlando Predators in the championship game of the Arena Football League.
September 3 1995 Mountain Dew Southern 500: Jeff Gordon won a running of what is now the Sprint Cup Series in Darlington County, South Carolina.
September 4 Fourth World Conference on Women: A UN conference on women's rights convened in Beijing.
September 5 Fourth World Conference on Women: First lady Hillary Clinton delivered a speech entitled Women's Rights Are Human Rights, criticizing state and cultural practices that cause harm to women.
September 7 1995 MTV Video Music Awards: An awards ceremony was held in New York City for music videos.
September 8 Murder of Michael Nigg: Waiter Michael Nigg was shot during a robbery in Los Angeles.
UFC 7: An Ultimate Fighting Championship event was held in Buffalo, New York.
September 9 1995 Ms. Olympia: Lenda Murray won a women's bodybuilding contest in Atlanta.
September 10 1995 Mr. Olympia: Dorian Yates won a men's bodybuilding contest in Atlanta.
September 15 Fourth World Conference on Women: The conference ended. The participating states, including the United States, issued the Beijing Declaration committing themselves to take action to improve the status of women.
Hurricane Marilyn: A hurricane made landfall in the United States Virgin Islands which would kill one person in Puerto Rico.
September 16 Miss America 1996: Shawntel Smith won a beauty pageant held in Atlantic City, New Jersey.
September 17 Murder of Stephanie Kuhen: Members of the Avenues, a gang, shot into a vehicle in Los Angeles, killing a three-year-old girl.
September 20 Operation Deliberate Force: The operation was concluded following the withdrawal of BPC artillery from an area around Sarajevo.
September 22 Republican Party presidential primaries, 1996: Businessman Steve Forbes announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for the presidency.
1995 Alaska Boeing E-3 Sentry accident: An airborne early warning aircraft crashed near Elmendorf Air Force Base after colliding with birds on takeoff.
September 24 1995 Ryder Cup: The European team defeated the American team in a golf competition held in Pittsford (village), New York.
September 30 The 310th Air Refueling Squadron was inactivated.
October 1 Democratic congressman Mel Reynolds resigned his seat representing Illinois's 2nd congressional district after being convicted for crimes related to his sexual relationship with a minor.
Republican senator Bob Packwood of Oregon resigned, under threat of expulsion, after it came to light that he had sexually harassed and assaulted numerous women.
October 2 1995 American League West tie-breaker game: The Seattle Mariners defeated the California Angels in a tiebreaker game in Seattle to advance to the American League Division Series.
The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit held in a decision in Microsoft Corp. v. DAK Industries, Inc. that a software license agreement should be considered a lump sale of software units, making the licensor an unsecured creditor in the event of bankruptcy.
October 3 Mount Vision fire: A wildfire began on the Point Reyes National Seashore which would cause some six million dollars in damage over the next thirteen days.
October 4 Hurricane Opal: A hurricane made landfall in the Florida Panhandle which would kill thirteen Americans before dissipating two days later.
October 8 The Double: A double gave the Seattle Mariners a victory over the New York Yankees in the eleventh inning of a divisional game in Seattle, clinching the series.
October 9 1995 Palo Verde, Arizona derailment: A train was derailed by saboteurs near Palo Verde, Arizona, killing one.
October 10 Democratic congressman Norman Mineta of California's 15th congressional district resigned his seat.
October 12 Blackville-Hilda High School shooting: A student fatally shot a teacher before committing suicide at a high school in Blackville, South Carolina.
October 14 1995 National League Championship Series: The Atlanta Braves defeated the Cincinnati Reds in four games, the fourth in Atlanta, to advance to the World Series.
October 16 Million Man March: Several hundred thousand black men gathered in Washington, D.C. for a prayer event called by Louis Farrakhan of the Nation of Islam and organized by the National African American Leadership Summit.
Classical World Chess Championship 1995: Incumbent champion Garry Kasparov defeated challenger Viswanathan Anand after eighteen games of a twenty-game chess match in New York City.
October 17 1995 Skate America: A figure skating competition opened in Detroit.
1995 American League Championship Series: The Cleveland Indians defeated the Seattle Mariners in Seattle in the sixth game of the series and advanced to the World Series.
October 23 Trial of Yolanda Saldívar: Saldívar was found guilty of first-degree murder in Selena's death.
October 25 1995 Fox River Grove bus–train collision: A train crashed into a stopped school bus in Fox River Grove, Illinois, killing seven students.
October 28 1995 World Series: The Atlanta Braves defeated the Cleveland Indians in the World Series in six games, the sixth in Atlanta.
November 4 Northern Mariana Islands parliamentary expenses referendum, 1995: A referendum on increasing the budget of the legislature of the Northern Mariana Islands was rejected by voters.
November 7 United States gubernatorial elections, 1995: Gubernatorial elections were held in Kentucky, Louisiana and Mississippi. The Democratic Party lost one seat.
Houston mayoral election, 1995: Incumbent mayor Bob Lanier (politician) of Houston was reelected with eighty-three percent of the vote.
November 8 The Jerusalem Embassy Act, which calls for the recognition of Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and for the American embassy to be moved to Jerusalem from Tel Aviv, became law.
November 10 Democratic congressman Michael Parker (politician) of Mississippi's 4th congressional district changed parties to become a Republican.
November 12 American Airlines Flight 1572: A commercial flight from Chicago to Windsor Locks, Connecticut struck trees and an instrument landing system antenna on landing, causing some nine million dollars in damage to the aircraft.
1995 NAPA 500: Dale Earnhardt won a running of what is now the Sprint Cup Series in Hampton, Georgia.
November 13 1995 WTA Tour Championships: A women's tennis tournament opened in New York City which would see Steffi Graf win the singles tournament and Jana Novotná and Arantxa Sánchez Vicario the doubles.
November 14 United States federal government shutdowns of 1995–1996: Nonessential operations of the federal government ceased after the failure of Clinton and the Congress to agree to a budget.
November 15 Richland High School shooting: Student James Rouse shot and killed one teacher and one student at a high school in Lynnville, Tennessee.
November 18 Louisiana gubernatorial election, 1995: Republican Murphy J. Foster Jr. was elected governor of Louisiana in a runoff election with sixty-four percent of the vote.
November 19 United States federal government shutdowns of 1995–1996: Clinton signed a short-term appropriations bill into law, ending the shutdown.
November 20 23rd International Emmy Awards: An awards ceremony was held in New York City for foreign television.
The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit held in a decision in Price v. United States that the government was exempt from suit under the principle of sovereign immunity, as it had not expressly waived its immunity in the particular tort of which it was accused under the Federal Tort Claims Act.
November 21 The District Court for the Northern District of California held in a decision in Religious Technology Center v. Netcom On-Line Communication Services, Inc. that an internet service provider or computer bulletin board service cannot automatically be held liable for acts of copyright infringement by its users.
November 22 Murder of Elisa Izquierdo: Six-year-old Elisa Izquierdo was beaten to death by her mother in New York City.
November 28 An act was signed into law which established the National Highway System and authorized federal grants to the states for its maintenance.
November 29 The Supreme Court held in a decision in Thompson v. Keohane that the question of whether a suspect is in police custody and must therefore be read a Miranda warning is a matter of law, and that, therefore, federal courts need not defer to state courts on this question as they must in matters of fact.
December 1 Democratic congressman Jimmy Hayes of Louisiana's 7th congressional district changed parties to become a Republican.
December 2 1995 SEC Championship Game: The Florida Gators defeated the Arkansas Razorbacks in a college football conference championship game in Atlanta.
December 5 In a decision in Things Remembered, Inc. v. Petrarca, the Supreme Court held that courts of appeals lack jurisdiction to review remand orders which remove a case from a federal to a state court.
December 6 The Supreme Court held in a decision in Bailey v. United States that the mere possession of a firearm did not constitute the use of the firearm under a commonly used section of Title 18 of the United States Code dealing with drug crime.
December 10 1995 NCAA Division I Men's Soccer Championship: The Wisconsin Badgers won the final match of a college soccer tournament in Richmond, Virginia.
December 12 San Francisco mayoral election, 1995: Willie Brown (politician) defeated incumbent and fellow Democrat Frank Jordan to become mayor of San Francisco.
Illinois's 2nd congressional district special election, 1995: An election was held to the House seat representing Illinois's 2nd congressional district, vacant after Reynolds's resignation. Democrat Jesse Jackson Jr. won with seventy-six percent of the vote.
Republican Tom Campbell (California politician) was seated following a special election to Mineta's vacant House seat representing California's 15th congressional district.
December 14 Bosnian War: Serbia and Montenegro, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Croatia signed the Dayton Agreement in Paris, ending the war.
1995 Las Vegas Bowl: The Toledo Rockets defeated the Nevada Wolf Pack in a college football bowl game held in Whitney, Nevada.
December 15 Democratic congressman Walter R. Tucker III resigned to face trial for demanding bribes during his tenure as mayor of Compton, California.
December 16 United States federal government shutdowns of 1995–1996: The short-term spending bill expired without a deal on an annual budget, forcing nonessential operations of the government to again shut down.
Ultimate Ultimate 1995: Dan Severn won a mixed martial arts tournament held in Denver.
December 19 The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995, which requires the registration of lobbyists and the disclosure of lobbying activities, was signed into law.
December 22 The Private Securities Litigation Reform Act, which increases the requirements for filing suit under securities law, was passed over Bill Clinton's veto.
December 25 1995 Aloha Bowl: The Kansas Jayhawks defeated the UCLA Bruins in a college football bowl game held in Honolulu.
December 27 1995 Copper Bowl: The Texas Tech Red Raiders defeated the Air Force Falcons in a college football bowl game in Tucson, Arizona.
December 28 1995 Alamo Bowl: The Texas A&M Aggies defeated the Michigan Wolverines in a college football bowl game in San Antonio.
The Housing for Older Persons Act, which clarifies a portion of the Civil Rights Act of 1968 exempting senior housing from age discrimination requirements, was signed into law.
December 29 1995 Holiday Bowl: The Kansas State Wildcats defeated the Colorado State Rams in a college football bowl game in San Diego.
1995 Sun Bowl: The Iowa Hawkeyes defeated the Washington Huskies in a college football bowl game in El Paso, Texas.
The ICC Termination Act of 1995 was signed into law, abolishing the Interstate Commerce Commission and establishing the Surface Transportation Board effective January 1 to take on some of its functions.
1995 Independence Bowl: The LSU Tigers defeated the Michigan State Spartans in a college football bowl game held in Shreveport, Louisiana.
December 30 1995 Liberty Bowl: The East Carolina Pirates defeated the Stanford Cardinal in a college football bowl game in Memphis, Tennessee.
1995 Carquest Bowl: The North Carolina Tar Heels defeated the Arkansas Razorbacks in a college football bowl game in Miami Gardens, Florida.
1995 Peach Bowl: The Virginia Cavaliers defeated the Georgia Bulldogs in a college football bowl game in Atlanta.
December 31 1995 Sugar Bowl: The Virginia Tech Hokies defeated the Texas Longhorns in a college football bowl game in New Orleans.
1996 TWA Flight 800: A flight exploded off Long Island, killing all 230 aboard.
Khobar Towers bombing: A bombing left nineteen American servicemen dead in Saudi Arabia.
Centennial Olympic Park bombing: A bombing in Atlanta killed one and injured 111.
August 22 The Welfare Reform Act of 1996, replacing the AFDC with TANF, was signed into law.[642][643]
U.S. presidential election, 1996: Bill Clinton was reelected to a second term as President of the United States, defeating presidential candidates Bob Dole and Ross Perot.
United States federal government shutdown of 1995 and 1996: The shutdown ended.
1997 Clinton banned federal funds from being used for human cloning research.[644]
Sparked by a global economic crisis scare, the Dow Jones Industrial Average followed world markets and plummeted 554.26, or 7.18%, to 7,161.15.
1998 Former Arkansas state employee Paula Jones accused Clinton of sexual harassment.
Lewinsky scandal: Bill Clinton was accused of having a sexual relationship with 22-year-old White House intern, Monica Lewinsky.
1998 U.S. embassy bombings: 224 were killed in bombings in Tanzania and Kenya.
Gay college student Matthew Shepard was brutally murdered near the University of Wyoming.
1999 Dennis Hastert of Illinois becomes Speaker of the House of Representatives.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 10,006.78.
April 20 Two teenage students murdered 13 other students and teachers at Columbine High School.
1999 Oklahoma tornado outbreak: A violent tornado outbreak in Oklahoma killed fifty people and produced a tornado which caused $1 billion in damage.
EgyptAir Flight 990: The first officer deliberately crashed a plane south of Nantucket, Massachusetts, killing 217.
Along with the rest of the world, the United States prepared for the possible effects of the Y2K bug in computers, which was feared destined to cause computers to become inoperable and wreak havoc.
2000 October 12 USS Cole bombing: The USS Cole was bombed in Yemeni waters, killing seventeen United States Navy sailors.

21st century[edit]

Year Date Event
2001 January 20 First inauguration of George W. Bush: George W. Bush was inaugurated the forty-third President of the United States.[645]
June 7 The Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 was signed into law by President George W. Bush.[646]
September 11 September 11 terrorist attacks: Nineteen terrorists hijacked four planes and crashed them into the World Trade Center in New York City, the Pentagon in Arlington County, Virginia, and an open field near Shanksville, Pennsylvania, killing 2,996 people and injuring over 6,000.[647]
September 18 2001 Anthrax attacks: Anthrax attacks killed five and infected seventeen more through the mail system.[648]
October 7 War in Afghanistan: The United States launched an invasion of Afghanistan.[649]
October 26 The USA PATRIOT Act, increasing law enforcement agencies' ability to conduct searches in cases of suspected terrorism, was signed into law.[650]
November 12 American Airlines Flight 587: A flight crashed in Queens, New York, killing 265.[651]
2002 June 13 The United States officially withdraws from the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty.[652]
January 8 The No Child Left Behind Act education reform bill was signed into law.[653]
October 2–22 Beltway sniper attacks: Ten people were killed and three were injured in attacks around the Washington, D.C. area.[654]
November 25 The United States Department of Homeland Security was created.[655]
2003 February 1 Space Shuttle Columbia disaster: The Space Shuttle Columbia disintegrated on reentry into the Earth's atmosphere, killing all seven astronauts aboard.[656]
February 17 2003 E2 nightclub stampede: A nightclub stampede in Chicago, Illinois killed twenty-one.[657]
February 20 The Station nightclub fire: A fire caused by pyrotechnics at a nightclub in West Warwick, Rhode Island killed 100 people and injured over 230.[658]
March 19 Invasion of Iraq: The United States, United Kingdom, Australia and Poland invaded Iraq.[659]
December 13 Capture of Saddam Hussein: In Iraq, deposed Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was captured by United States special forces.[660]
2004 February 4 The social networking website Facebook was launched.[661]
2004 Atlantic hurricane season: Four deadly and damaging hurricanes impacted Florida, killing a combined one hundred people in the United States and producing over $50 billion in damage.[662]
November 2 U.S. presidential election, 2004; President George W. Bush was reelected.[663]
2005 January 20 Second inauguration of George W. Bush: George W. Bush was inaugurated to his second term.[664]
August 23–30 Hurricane Katrina: A hurricane devastated the Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama coastlines killing at least 1,836 people and causing $81 billion in damage.[665]
2006 November 7 The Democratic Party regained control of both houses of Congress and gained control of a majority of state governorships.[666][667][668]
2007 January 3 Democrat Nancy Pelosi became the first woman to become Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives.[669]
January 10 Iraq War troop surge of 2007: George W. Bush ordered the substantial increase of the number of United States troops in Iraq.[670]
April 16 Virginia Tech massacre: A South Korean student shot and killed thirty-two other students and professors before killing himself.[671]
August 1 The I-35W Mississippi River bridge in Minneapolis, Minnesota collapsed, killing thirteen people.[672]
December Late-2000s recession: A recession began.[673][674][675]
2008 February 5–6 2008 Super Tuesday tornado outbreak: An outbreak of tornadoes killed over sixty people and produced $1 billion in damage across Arkansas, Kentucky, Tennessee, and Alabama.[676]
September 1–14 Hurricane Ike: A hurricane killed 100 people along the Texas coast, producing $31 billion in damage and contributing to rising oil prices.[677]
July 11 Oil prices in the United States hit a record $147 per barrel.[678]
Global financial crisis in September 2008: The stock market crashed.[679][680][681]
September 14 Bankruptcy of Lehman Brothers: Investment bank Lehman Brothers files for bankruptcy, the largest in U.S. history.[679]
November 4 U.S. presidential election, 2008: Barack Obama was elected the forty-fourth President of the United States.[682]
2009 January 20 Inauguration of Barack Obama: Obama was inaugurated the forty-fourth President of the United States.[683]
February 17 President Barack Obama signed the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009, a $787 billion economic stimulus package.[684]
Tea Party protests: The first of a series of protests, focusing on smaller government, fiscal responsibility, individual freedoms and conservative views of the Constitution, were conducted across the country.[685]
June 25 Death of Michael Jackson: Pop icon Michael Jackson died.[686]
August 8 Sonia Sotomayor was sworn in as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court; becoming the first Latino Justice.[687]
November 5 Fort Hood shooting: Nidal Malik Hasan killed twelve servicemen and injured thirty-one.[688]
2010 February 23 The United States Navy lifted its ban on women in submarines.[689]
March 23 The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) was signed into law by President Barack Obama.[690]
April 20 Deepwater Horizon oil spill: The BP oil rig Deepwater Horizon exploded in the Gulf of Mexico, killing 11 workers and spilling 4.9 million barrels of oil into the Gulf over an 87-day period; being the largest marine oil spill in the history of the petroleum industry.[691]
July 21 The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act was signed into law; establishing the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.[692]
November 2 United States Senate elections, 2010: The Republican Party gained five seats, to forty-seven, reducing the Democratic presence in the Senate to fifty-one. Two seats remained in the hands of independents.[693]
United States House of Representatives elections, 2010: The Republican Party gained sixty-two seats, giving them an absolute majority of 242 in the House and reducing the Democratic presence to 193.[694]
November 28 United States diplomatic cables leak: WikiLeaks began to release classified diplomatic documents to the international press.[695]
December 22 The Senate ratified the New START treaty.[696]
December 22 The Don't Ask, Don't Tell Repeal Act of 2010 was signed into law, ending the Don't ask, don't tell policy regarding homosexuals in the United States Armed Forces.[697]
2011 January 8 2011 Tucson shooting: A gunman targeting Democratic Representative Gabrielle Giffords critically injured Giffords and killed six others, including federal judge John Roll, in Tucson, Arizona.[698]
March 19 Operation Odyssey Dawn: The United States began air and cruise missile attacks against Libya.[699]
April 25–28 April 25–28, 2011 tornado outbreak: The largest tornado outbreak ever in United States history occurs in the American Midwest and Southern United States killing 348 People and causing 11 Billion Dollars in Damage.
May 2 Death of Osama bin Laden: Al-Qaeda head Osama bin Laden was killed by United States forces in Abbottabad, Pakistan.[700]
May 22 Joplin Tornado: An EF-5 tornado tore through Joplin, Missouri, killing 161, and causing $2.8 Billion in damage, including the destruction of a large portion of the main retail strip, a hospital, the high school, a middle school, and several elementary schools.
August 2 United States debt-ceiling crisis: The Budget Control Act of 2011 was signed into law, increasing the legal limit on federal government debt in order to prevent default and establishing the United States Congress Joint Select Committee on Deficit Reduction.[701]
August 5 United States federal government credit-rating downgrade, 2011: The credit-rating arm of Standard & Poor's reduced the rating of United States federal government debt from AAA to AA+.[702]
August 8 August 2011 stock markets fall: Major United States stock market indices dropped in value by some two and a half trillion dollars.[703]
September 17 The populist Occupy Wall Street protest movement made camp in Zuccotti Park in New York City.[704]
December 18 Withdrawal of U.S. troops from Iraq: The last United States troops withdrew from Iraq under the terms of the U.S.–Iraq Status of Forces Agreement.[705]
2012 October 25–30 Hurricane Sandy: A devastating hurricane wreaks havoc for the Eastern United States coast. There were many states severely impacted by the hurricane, especially New York and New Jersey, which took a direct hit from the storm.
November 6 United States presidential election, 2012: Barack Obama is reelected as president.[706]
December 14 Sandy Hook Elementary School shooting: Occurs in Newtown, Connecticut killing 20 Children and 6 Staff Members in Sandy Hook Elementary School, perpetrated by a 20 Year Old, Adam Lanza.
2013 January 20 Barack Obama is inaugurated for his second term as president.[707]
April 15 Boston Marathon bombings: Two pressure cooker bombs explode during the Boston Marathon.[708]
June Global surveillance disclosures: The revelations of the NSA's PRISM, Boundless Informant and XKeyscore domestic surveillance programs were first published by The Guardian and Washington Post newspapers.[709][710][711]
2014 April 16 Flight MH370 of Malaysian airlines went missing and was never found over the months and months of searching even with the modern technology and thousands of not just Americans but people around the world.[712]
May 23 2014 Isla Vista killings occurs, killing 6, and wounding 14 others, perpetrated by elliot rodger.
June President Obama orders the return of a small number of troops to Iraq to help bolster Iraqi and Kurdish military forces in their war with the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant.[713]
August 9 Michael Brown was shot and killed, in what was ruled by a grand jury to be self-defense, by police officer Darren Wilson in Ferguson, Missouri, igniting protests and riots in the following months.[714]
November 3 New building, 1 World Trade Center, opens in New York City.[715]
November 4 In national elections, Republicans take control of the U.S. Senate and maintaining a majority in the House of Representatives.[716]
December 17 President Obama announces a restoration of full diplomatic relations with Cuba for the first time since 1961.[717]
2015 April 27 2015 Baltimore protests: Protests and rioting occur in Baltimore, Maryland after the death of Freddie Gray in police custody.
June 17 Charleston church shooting: A gunman killed 9, including a state senator in a church in Charleston, South Carolina.
June 26 Obergefell v. Hodges: Gay marriage is fully legalized in all 50 states.
July 20 Restoration of relations with Cuba.
December 2 2015 San Bernardino attack: Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik, a married radical Muslim couple, kills 14 people at a center for the developmentally disabled.
2016 January 2 Occupation of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge: an armed standoff in Oregon between armed anti-government militants and county, state, and federal law enforcement agencies takes place.
April 21 "Prince" Rogers Nelson dies at his home in Minnesota.
June 11 2016 Orlando Nightclub Shooting: An Islamic State soldier[citation needed], Omar Mateen, kills 49 and injures 53 at a gay nightclub in Orlando, before being shot and killed by an officer.
November 8 presidential election, 2016: Donald Trump wins the 2016 presidential elections, and will be the forty-fifth president of the United States.[718]
